front: What does GPU stand for?
back: Graphics Processing Unit - specialized processors for parallel computing tasks, essential for AI training and inference

front: What does TPU stand for?
back: Tensor Processing Unit - Google's custom AI accelerator chips optimized for machine learning workloads

front: What does DTC stand for in cooling?
back: Direct-to-Chip - liquid cooling method using cold plates attached directly to processors

front: What does CDU stand for?
back: Cooling Distribution Unit - equipment that interfaces between facility cooling loops and IT equipment cooling loops

front: What does PUE stand for?
back: Power Usage Effectiveness - metric measuring data center energy efficiency (total facility power / IT equipment power)

front: What does WUE stand for?
back: Water Usage Effectiveness - metric measuring water consumption efficiency (liters consumed per kWh of IT energy)

front: What does CRAH stand for?
back: Computer Room Air Handler - air handling unit designed specifically for data center cooling

front: What does CRAC stand for?
back: Computer Room Air Conditioner - traditional air conditioning unit for data centers, less efficient than CRAH

front: What does UPS stand for?
back: Uninterruptible Power Supply - provides backup power during outages and power quality conditioning

front: What does PDU stand for?
back: Power Distribution Unit - distributes electrical power to IT equipment at rack or facility level

front: What does SLD stand for?
back: Single Line Diagram - simplified electrical diagram showing power flow from utility to end equipment

front: What does VESDA stand for?
back: Very Early Smoke Detection Apparatus - detects microscopic particles before visible smoke formation

front: What does InfiniBand provide in AI data centers?
back: Low-latency, high-bandwidth networking up to 200 Gbps per port for AI cluster communication

front: What does 400GbE stand for?
back: 400 Gigabit Ethernet - current standard for AI backend networking

front: What is Ultra Ethernet?
back: Combines traditional Ethernet with InfiniBand-like features optimized for AI workloads

front: What does HVAC stand for?
back: Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning - building environmental control systems

front: What does AHU stand for?
back: Air Handling Unit - equipment that conditions and circulates air in buildings

front: What does VFD stand for?
back: Variable Frequency Drive - controls motor speed and torque by varying input frequency and voltage

front: What does BMS stand for?
back: Building Management System - computerized control system for building mechanical and electrical equipment

front: What does DCIM stand for?
back: Data Center Infrastructure Management - software for monitoring and managing data center assets

front: What does kW stand for and how does it differ from kWh?
back: Kilowatt (power at an instant) vs Kilowatt-hour (energy consumed over time)

front: What does MW stand for?
back: Megawatt - one million watts, typical measurement for large data center power capacity

front: What does kVA stand for?
back: Kilovolt-Ampere - apparent power measurement accounting for reactive power components

front: What does MTBF stand for?
back: Mean Time Between Failures - reliability metric for equipment expected operational time

front: What does MTTR stand for?
back: Mean Time To Repair - average time needed to restore equipment to operational status

front: What does SLA stand for?
back: Service Level Agreement - contractual commitment for service performance standards

front: What does RTO stand for?
back: Recovery Time Objective - maximum acceptable downtime after a disaster event

front: What does RPO stand for?
back: Recovery Point Objective - maximum acceptable data loss measured in time

front: What does CAPEX stand for?
back: Capital Expenditure - funds used to acquire, upgrade, and maintain physical assets

front: What does OPEX stand for?
back: Operational Expenditure - ongoing business costs for day-to-day operations

front: What does TCO stand for?
back: Total Cost of Ownership - complete cost of owning an asset over its entire lifecycle

front: What does ROI stand for?
back: Return on Investment - financial metric measuring investment efficiency and profitability

front: What does IRR stand for?
back: Internal Rate of Return - discount rate that makes net present value equal zero

front: What does NPV stand for?
back: Net Present Value - difference between present value of cash inflows and outflows

front: What does CFM stand for?
back: Cubic Feet per Minute - measurement of volumetric flow rate for air handling systems

front: What does BTU stand for?
back: British Thermal Unit - energy measurement equal to heat needed to raise 1 pound of water 1°F

front: What does COP stand for in cooling?
back: Coefficient of Performance - cooling efficiency ratio of heat removed to energy consumed

front: What does EER stand for?
back: Energy Efficiency Ratio - cooling efficiency measurement under specific operating conditions

front: What does SEER stand for?
back: Seasonal Energy Efficiency Ratio - cooling efficiency over entire cooling season

front: What does Delta T (ΔT) mean?
back: Temperature difference between two points, critical for cooling system design

front: What does GPM stand for?
back: Gallons Per Minute - flow rate measurement for liquid cooling systems

front: What does PSI stand for?
back: Pounds per Square Inch - pressure measurement for fluid systems

front: What does PSIG vs PSIA mean?
back: PSIG (gauge pressure relative to atmosphere) vs PSIA (absolute pressure including atmosphere)

front: What does IP rating stand for?
back: Ingress Protection - international standard for enclosure protection against particles and moisture

front: What does NEMA stand for?
back: National Electrical Manufacturers Association - develops standards for electrical equipment

front: What does IEEE stand for?
back: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers - develops electrical and technology standards

front: What does ANSI stand for?
back: American National Standards Institute - oversees development of voluntary consensus standards

front: What does ASHRAE stand for?
back: American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers - develops HVAC standards

front: What does TIA stand for?
back: Telecommunications Industry Association - develops telecommunications standards including TIA-942

front: What does NEC stand for?
back: National Electrical Code - standard for electrical installation safety in the United States

front: What does NFPA stand for?
back: National Fire Protection Association - develops fire safety codes and standards

front: What does LEED stand for?
back: Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design - green building certification program

front: What does BREEAM stand for?
back: Building Research Establishment Environmental Assessment Method - UK green building standard

front: What does ENERGY STAR mean for data centers?
back: EPA program recognizing energy-efficient data centers meeting specific performance criteria

front: What does ISO 14001 cover?
back: International standard for environmental management systems and sustainability

front: What does SOC stand for in compliance?
back: Service Organization Control - compliance framework for service organizations' internal controls

front: What does HIPAA stand for?
back: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act - healthcare data privacy regulation

front: What does PCI DSS stand for?
back: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard - security requirements for card payment processing

front: What does FISMA stand for?
back: Federal Information Security Management Act - federal information systems security framework

front: What does FedRAMP stand for?
back: Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program - cloud services security certification for government

front: What is the actual construction cost of Crusoe's Abilene Phase 1 facility?
back: $584 million for Phase 1 base construction (two buildings, ~967,000 sq ft)

front: How many GPUs can Crusoe house per building in Abilene?
back: Up to 100,000 GPUs per building

front: What is Crusoe's Water Usage Effectiveness (WUE) with their closed loop system?
back: Near zero water usage with zero-water evaporation closed-loop system

front: What is Crusoe's current cluster uptime percentage?
back: 99.98% cluster uptime ("Gold Standard" rating)

front: What cost savings does Crusoe achieve with their energy-first approach?
back: Up to 30% cost savings below market rates through direct clean energy sourcing

front: What is the total capacity of Crusoe's Abilene facility when fully built out?
back: 1.2 GW capacity across 8 buildings when fully built out

front: What are Crusoe's three primary business segments?
back: DFM (Digital Flare Mitigation), DRO (Digital Renewable Optimization), and Crusoe Cloud

front: How does Crusoe's closed loop cooling system eliminate water loss?
back: Proprietary direct-to-chip liquid cooling circulates coolant directly to GPUs eliminating evaporation

front: What is the typical power density range for AI training workloads?
back: 60-120kW+ per rack (compared to 5-10kW for traditional)

front: What power density projections are expected by 2028-2030?
back: 200-250kW per rack by 2028-2030

front: How much more efficient is 3-phase power compared to single-phase?
back: 1.7x more efficient power transmission and better load balancing

front: What voltage systems are commonly used in AI data centers?
back: 480V, 600V, and medium voltage systems for high power densities

front: What is the emerging power architecture to replace 12V systems?
back: 48V power architecture for 25% energy loss reduction

front: What are typical lead times for major electrical equipment?
back: 12-18 months for transformers, switchgear, and major electrical components

front: What is N+1 redundancy in power systems?
back: One spare/backup component for the entire system (if one fails, backup takes over)

front: What is 2N redundancy in power systems?
back: Fully duplicated systems with two independent power paths

front: What are typical rack PDU circuit ratings for AI equipment?
back: 20-60A circuits for rack-level power distribution

front: What is the capacity range for floor PDUs in AI data centers?
back: 500-2500kVA capacity for floor-mounted power distribution

front: What is the minimum generator fuel capacity requirement?
back: 24-72 hours minimum fuel capacity with paralleling capability

front: What UPS battery backup duration is typical during generator startup?
back: 5-10 minutes during generator startup sequence

front: What medium voltage levels are typical for AI data center utility feeds?
back: 13.2kV, 13.8kV, or 27.6kV requiring dedicated substations

front: What is the cost range for substations serving facilities exceeding 10MW?
back: $3-7 million for substations serving facilities exceeding 10MW

front: What percentage of traditional data center space can support AI power densities?
back: 25% of traditional space due to power infrastructure constraints

front: What percentage of heat load can direct-to-chip cooling remove?
back: 70-75% of heat load through liquid cooling plates

front: What are the two types of immersion cooling?
back: Single-phase (non-boiling) and dual-phase (boiling) immersion cooling

front: What power densities can immersion cooling support?
back: 100-150kW+ per rack for highest density applications

front: What chilled water supply temperatures are typical for AI data centers?
back: 45-55°F supply temperatures for enhanced heat removal

front: What ASHRAE operating temperature range applies to data centers?
back: 18-27°C (64-81°F) with 45-55% humidity per ASHRAE guidelines

front: What is the industry average PUE and what do leading operators achieve?
back: Industry average 1.56, leading operators achieve 1.09-1.10

front: At what power density do traditional CRAC units become inadequate?
back: Beyond 20-30kW per rack require liquid cooling supplementation

front: What CFM capacity range do Computer Room Air Handlers provide?
back: 1,000-5,000 CFM capacity with hot/cold aisle containment

front: What is the purpose of hot/cold aisle containment?
back: Prevents hot and cold air mixing, improving cooling efficiency

front: What cooling approach handles the highest power densities?
back: Immersion cooling supports the highest power densities (150kW+)

front: What is the current percentage of data centers with liquid cooling installed?
back: 22% of data centers have already installed liquid cooling

front: What is Microsoft's target WUE by 2030?
back: 0.3 L/kWh by 2030 for water usage effectiveness

front: What structural modifications are needed for AI retrofits?
back: Increase floor loading capacity and vertical clearance to 8-9 meters

front: What floor loading capacity increase is required for AI equipment?
back: From 3-5 KN/m² to 10-15 KN/m² for heavy AI equipment

front: What vertical clearance is needed for AI data centers?
back: 8-9 meters for proper airflow and equipment access

front: What does VESDA detect and when?
back: VESDA detects microscopic particles before visible smoke formation

front: What clean agents are used for equipment fire protection?
back: FM-200 and NOVEC 1230 for clean agent equipment protection

front: How do pre-action sprinkler systems work?
back: Double-interlock protection requiring both detector activation and sprinkler activation

front: What enhanced plumbing features are critical for liquid cooling?
back: Comprehensive leak detection throughout cooling loops and emergency shutoffs

front: What are the six levels of data center commissioning?
back: Factory testing, installation verification, system integration testing, performance validation, documentation, training

front: What is the commissioning process purpose?
back: Performance verification and documentation that all systems perform according to design

front: What percentage of AI data center retrofit cost do electrical systems represent?
back: 40-45% of total retrofit cost ($280-460 per square foot)

front: What is the total retrofit cost range per gross square foot?
back: $520-900 per gross square foot for complete AI retrofit

front: What percentage of AI data centers use design-build delivery?
back: 70-80% of AI data centers use design-build delivery

front: How does design-build compress traditional schedules?
back: From traditional 24-36 months to 12-18 months

front: How does a GMP contract structure work?
back: Owner pays actual costs plus contractor fee, cost overruns are contractor's responsibility

front: What are the main benefits of GMP contracts for AI projects?
back: Cost certainty, transparency, early contractor involvement, potential savings sharing

front: What does CMAR stand for and how does it work?
back: Construction Manager At Risk - early construction input while maintaining owner design control

front: Why do AI projects require higher contingencies?
back: Technology evolution, equipment changes, uncertain requirements, rapid innovation

front: What contingency percentage is typical for AI data center projects?
back: 10-15% of project budget for technology adaptations

front: What contract type provides maximum flexibility for evolving requirements?
back: Cost Plus contracts provide maximum flexibility for scope changes

front: Which hyperscaler has the largest 2025 AI infrastructure investment?
back: Amazon Web Services with over $100 billion over the next decade

front: What is CoreWeave's total funding and GPU count?
back: $12.7 billion in total funding, operating 45,000+ GPUs

front: How does Lambda Labs' H100 pricing compare to AWS?
back: $2.49/hour vs AWS's $12+/hour for H100 GPUs

front: What is Meta's 2025 investment amount and Louisiana facility scale?
back: $60-65 billion in 2025, Louisiana facility housing 1.3 million GPUs

front: Which contractors are building Meta's $10B Louisiana data center?
back: Turner Construction, DPR Construction, and Mortenson

front: What makes DPR Construction notable for AI data centers?
back: Advanced Virtual Design and Construction (VDC) capabilities and technology integration

front: What is Digital Realty's AI strategy and partnership?
back: $7 billion joint venture with Blackstone for AI-ready data centers

front: What power density does CyrusOne's Intelliscale support?
back: Up to 300kW per rack with Intelliscale AI services

front: What are the main components in a typical AI data center single line diagram?
back: Utility feed → Transformers → Switchgear → UPS → PDUs → Rack PDUs

front: What is the purpose of transformers in data center electrical systems?
back: Convert utility voltage to appropriate levels for data center equipment

front: What network bandwidth does InfiniBand provide for AI clusters?
back: Up to 200 Gbps per port for low-latency AI cluster communication

front: What is the current standard for AI backend networking?
back: 400 Gigabit Ethernet (400GbE) for AI backend networking

front: What network standard is expected to dominate by 2025?
back: 800 Gigabit Ethernet (800GbE) expected to dominate by 2025

front: What makes InfiniBand preferred for AI training clusters?
back: Low-latency, high-bandwidth characteristics essential for AI training workloads

front: How do switchgear components function in a data center SLD?
back: Control and protect electrical circuits, enable maintenance isolation and safety

front: What is Ultra Ethernet and why is it important for AI?
back: Combines traditional Ethernet with InfiniBand-like features optimized for AI workloads

front: What does CPM stand for in construction scheduling?
back: Critical Path Method - scheduling technique that identifies the longest sequence of dependent activities

front: What is the critical path in a construction schedule?
back: The longest sequence of activities that determines the minimum project duration

front: What is float or slack in project scheduling?
back: Amount of time an activity can be delayed without delaying the project completion

front: What is the difference between total float and free float?
back: Total float affects project completion, free float only affects successor activities

front: What is fast tracking in schedule compression?
back: Overlapping activities that were originally planned in sequence to compress schedule

front: What is crashing in schedule compression?
back: Adding resources to critical path activities to reduce their duration

front: What are the key components of a Gantt chart?
back: Tasks, durations, dependencies, resources, timeline, milestones, and progress tracking

front: What is resource leveling in project scheduling?
back: Smoothing resource demand to avoid over-allocation while maintaining critical path

front: What is the difference between lag and lead time?
back: Lag adds delay between activities, lead allows successor to start before predecessor finishes

front: What are the four types of task dependencies?
back: Finish-to-Start (FS), Start-to-Start (SS), Finish-to-Finish (FF), Start-to-Finish (SF)

front: What is a milestone in project scheduling?
back: Significant project event or deliverable with zero duration marking key completion points

front: What is the difference between duration and work in scheduling?
back: Duration is elapsed time, work is effort hours required to complete the task

front: What is baseline schedule and why is it important?
back: Original approved schedule used for performance measurement and change control

front: What are common schedule risks in data center construction?
back: Long-lead equipment procurement, utility delays, weather, permit approvals, design changes

front: How do you calculate schedule variance (SV)?
back: SV = Earned Value (EV) - Planned Value (PV)

front: What are the five phases of project management lifecycle?
back: Initiation, Planning, Execution, Monitoring & Controlling, Closeout

front: What is the project management triangle (triple constraint)?
back: Scope, Time, and Cost - changing one affects the others

front: What does EVM stand for and what does it measure?
back: Earned Value Management - measures project performance against scope, schedule, and cost

front: What is the difference between proactive and reactive risk management?
back: Proactive identifies and prevents risks, reactive responds after risks occur

front: What are the key elements of a project charter?
back: Project authorization, objectives, scope, stakeholders, success criteria, constraints

front: What is the difference between quality assurance and quality control?
back: QA prevents defects through process, QC detects defects through inspection

front: What is a work breakdown structure (WBS)?
back: Hierarchical breakdown of project deliverables and work packages

front: What is the purpose of a project kickoff meeting?
back: Align team on objectives, scope, roles, communication, and project approach

front: What are the key components of project communication management?
back: Stakeholder identification, communication planning, information distribution, reporting

front: What is change control process in construction projects?
back: Formal procedure for requesting, evaluating, approving, and implementing changes

front: What is the difference between functional and matrix organization structures?
back: Functional has clear hierarchy, matrix has dual reporting relationships

front: What are the key elements of project closeout?
back: Final deliverables, documentation, lessons learned, contract closure, team release

front: What is value engineering and when is it most effective?
back: Systematic review to optimize cost, function, and quality - most effective in design phase

front: What are the key performance indicators (KPIs) for construction projects?
back: Schedule performance, cost performance, quality metrics, safety indicators, stakeholder satisfaction

front: What is the difference between scope creep and scope change?
back: Scope creep is uncontrolled expansion, scope change is formal approved modification
